online.common
Class HitPoint

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.geom.Point2D
      java.awt.Point
          online.common.HitPoint
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, PlayConstants
public class HitPoint
extends java.awt.Point
implements PlayConstants

this extension of Point is the collection point for information about the location of the mouse, and the object it points at.

Author:
ddyer
See Also:
StartDragging, StopDragging, paintCanvas, Serialized Form

Field Detail

spriteRect

public java.awt.Rectangle spriteRect

spriteColor

public java.awt.Color spriteColor

helpObject

public java.lang.Object helpObject
if not null, the object that is the focus of mouse help

hitObject

public java.lang.Object hitObject
the object "hit" by the mouse. This is determined entirely by the paintCanvas routine and interpreted solely by the canvas. It's usually some interesting object such as a board cell or a rectangle.

col

public char col
conventionally, the board column hit by the mouse.

row

public int row
conventionally, the board row hit by the mouse.

hitCode

public CellId hitCode
an integer code indicating the object hit by the mouse. negative numbers are usually sustem defined codes.

HitNoWhere is the code for nothing identified as hit yet. Various stock widgets use other negative values. You should use positive values for your hitcodes.

dragging

public boolean dragging
true if the hit object has been picked up and is being dragged around by the mouse. This is independent of if the mouse button is currently down or up.

The canvas startDragging method should set this flag if this kind of pickup event has occurred.

See Also:
StartDragging, exCanvas.StopDragging(online.common.HitPoint), RepaintManager.paintCanvas(java.awt.Graphics, boolean, online.common.HitPoint)

down

public boolean down
true if the mouse button is currently down.

arrow

public StockArt arrow
when the mouse is determined to be pointing at something that can be picked up or dropped, set this to a piece of StockArt to be displayed. You must also set awidth to a suitable size, and (eventually) call DrawArrow to actuallly do the drawing.

See Also:
StockArt

awidth

public int awidth
the width of the StockArt rectangle. If arrow is not null, awidth must also be set to a reasonable value.

See Also:
DrawArrow

a_x

public int a_x
the x offset to display the Stockart, which will default to the mouse position

See Also:
DrawArrow

a_y

public int a_y
the y offset to display the StockArt, which will default to the mouse position

See Also:
DrawArrow

hit_x

public int hit_x
the center x of the hit object, which will default to the mouse location

hit_y

public int hit_y
the center y of the hit object, which will default to the mouse location

hit_index

public int hit_index
in a drawStack operation, the first index at which a hit occurred

hit_width

public int hit_width
the width of the sensitive area when hit

hit_height

public int hit_height
the height of the sensitive area when hit

highlightColor

public java.awt.Color highlightColor
if not null, a highlight rectangle is drawn with this color

Method Detail

setButton

public void setButton(int buttonMask)

drawChipHighlight

public void drawChipHighlight(java.awt.Graphics gc)
if highlightColor is not null, draw a box around the sensitive area for the object actually hit. this is done by exCanvas.DrawArrow(java.awt.Graphics, online.common.HitPoint), after other drawing, so the highlight will be on top.

Parameters:
gc -
